lessonOverview.title: Unit 7 - Lesson 1
structures: A: When have you got PE?
B: I’ve got PE on Friday.
A: When has he/she got music?
B: He’s/She’s got music on Monday.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six school subjects (art, maths, science, music, social studies, PE) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show subject flashcards. Play “Fast Point”: T says “Maths!”—students point to the correct image on the board or in their SB.
stretchStrategies: Lost & Found Roleplay – Create a “lost property desk” in class. One student is the staff member, others come up asking: “Whose watch is this?” “It’s Lan’s.” Use objects/cards to practise vocab + speaking + grammar in context.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about school subjects using “When have you got...?” / “When has he/she got...?” and respond with “I’ve got... on (day).” / “He’s/She’s got... on (day).”
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Do a mingle: Students walk and ask “When have you got PE?” Partners answer and record one answer on their timetable sheet.
stretchStrategies: Lost & Found Roleplay – Create a “lost property desk” in class. One student is the staff member, others come up asking: “Whose watch is this?” “It’s Lan’s.” Use objects/cards to practise vocab + speaking + grammar in context.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “When have you got ___?” / “When has he/she got ___?” / “I’ve got ___ on ___.” / “He’s/She’s got ___ on ___.” to talk about school subjects.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write a weekly timetable on the board. Ask Qs: “When has Anna got music?” Students respond using full sentence frames.
stretchStrategies: Lost & Found Roleplay – Create a “lost property desk” in class. One student is the staff member, others come up asking: “Whose watch is this?” “It’s Lan’s.” Use objects/cards to practise vocab + speaking + grammar in context.

items: A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
